author: .vbuterin
content: This design still has the property that if the state gets big that parts of it start getting completely forgotten, that would be really problematic right?

author: .vbuterin
content: Like for example, if two adjacent accounts A and B are in the inactive state and both get forgotten (nobody bothers storing them anymore), then it would no longer be possible to create anything between A and B in the inactive state

author: .vbuterin
content: And so if something gets created within that interval in the *active state*, then when it has to be moved, there is no way to progress the chain

author: .vbuterin
content: (to be clear, I don't think this is fatal, it's just a limitation of the statelessness schemes that I've seen so far that either you have this property that the inactive state must still be small enough to have a guarantee that _someone_ stores each part of it, or there is a risk that entire address ranges get disabled like this)
